channel.title: Munros on Ian Nelson
channel.description: Recent content in Munros on Ian Nelson

item.title: Paulo's Last Munro Photos
item.description: I’ve finally gotten round to processing and uploading photos from Paulo’s Last Munro weekend. The weather on Ben More was truly appalling, so the majority of the images were, unsurprisingly, taken within the cosy confines of the Craignure Inn, who gave us a wonderfully warm welcome.
item.content:encoded: I’ve finally gotten round to processing and uploading photos from Paulo’s Last Munro weekend. The weather on Ben More was truly appalling, so the majority of the images were, unsurprisingly, taken within the cosy confines of the Craignure Inn, who gave us a wonderfully warm welcome.

item.title: The Drumochter Four
item.description:
Remind me again why I do this kind of thing in January?

Thanks to Alex for the companionship on this greyest of days.

  • Geal Charn (917m)
  • A’Mharconaich (975m)
  • Beinn Udlamain (1011m)
  • Sgairneach Mhor (991m)
item.content:encoded:
Remind me again why I do this kind of thing in January?

Thanks to Alex for the companionship on this greyest of days.

  • Geal Charn (917m)
  • A’Mharconaich (975m)
  • Beinn Udlamain (1011m)
  • Sgairneach Mhor (991m)

item.title: Beinn Alligin
item.description:
Popping my Torridonian cherry on Beinn Alligin.

  • Sgurr Mhor (986m / 3235ft)
  • Tom na Gruagaich (922m / 3025ft)

item.title: A Couple of Glen Carron Hills
item.description:
Two of the hills that rise above Glen Carron.

  • Moruisg (928m / 3045ft)
  • Sgurr nan Ceannaichean (915m / 3002ft)
item.content:encoded:
Two of the hills that rise above Glen Carron.

  • Moruisg (928m / 3045ft)
  • Sgurr nan Ceannaichean (915m / 3002ft)

item.title: The Ring of Steall, Mamores
item.description:
A superlative day in the hills with Richard, Melanie, Hugh and Harriet.

A cloudy start at low heights, but as we ascended higher we broke through a cloud inversion, being presented with stunning blue skies and incredible views across to Ben Nevis and the Carn Mor Dearg arete.
item.content:encoded:
A superlative day in the hills with Richard, Melanie, Hugh and Harriet.

A cloudy start at low heights, but as we ascended higher we broke through a cloud inversion, being presented with stunning blue skies and incredible views across to Ben Nevis and the Carn Mor Dearg arete.

item.title: Beinn a'Bheithir
item.description: A great day bagging the two Munros that make up Beinn a’Bheithir – Sgorr Dheargh (1024m) and Sgorr Dhonuill (1001m)
item.content:encoded: A great day bagging the two Munros that make up Beinn a’Bheithir – Sgorr Dheargh (1024m) and Sgorr Dhonuill (1001m)

item.title: Buachaille Etive Beag
item.description: The little sibling to Buachaille Etive Mor.
item.content:encoded: The little sibling to Buachaille Etive Mor.

item.title: Four Big Cairngorms
item.description:
Four big ones in the bag, thanks to an overnight stay at Corrour Bothy:

  • Braeriach (1296m)
  • The Devil’s Point (Bod an Deamhain) (1004m)
  • Cairn Toul (1291m)
  • Sgor an Lochain Uaine (1258m)

It was at some point on this day that my Nokia 5510, won during last year’s Nokia Game, got wet and died.
item.content:encoded:
Four big ones in the bag, thanks to an overnight stay at Corrour Bothy:

  • Braeriach (1296m)
  • The Devil’s Point (Bod an Deamhain) (1004m)
  • Cairn Toul (1291m)
  • Sgor an Lochain Uaine (1258m)

It was at some point on this day that my Nokia 5510, won during last year’s Nokia Game, got wet and died.

item.title: Ben Nevis
item.description: On which I bagged the UK’s highest peak, Ben Nevis (1344m), via the curvaceous Carn Mor Dearg arête.
item.content:encoded: On which I bagged the UK’s highest peak, Ben Nevis (1344m), via the curvaceous Carn Mor Dearg arête.

item.title: Bla Bheinn (Blaven)
item.description: The Foot and Mouth outbreak fortunately did not prevent us from having a fine day bagging Bla Bheinn on the Isle of Skye.
item.content:encoded: The Foot and Mouth outbreak fortunately did not prevent us from having a fine day bagging Bla Bheinn on the Isle of Skye.

item.title: Sgorr Ruadh and Beinn Liath Mhor
item.description: Another great day on snow-kissed hills.
item.content:encoded: Another great day on snow-kissed hills.

item.title: Aonach Beag
item.description: On which we summitted the seventh-highest mountain in Scotland, the 1234m Aonach Beag. Plans to continue across to neighbouring Aonach Mor had to be abandoned due to poor visibility.
item.content:encoded: On which we summitted the seventh-highest mountain in Scotland, the 1234m Aonach Beag. Plans to continue across to neighbouring Aonach Mor had to be abandoned due to poor visibility.

item.title: The Fisherfield Forest
item.description: A couple of days in the wonderfully remote Fisherfield Forest, staying at the delightful Shenavall Bothy.
item.content:encoded: A couple of days in the wonderfully remote Fisherfield Forest, staying at the delightful Shenavall Bothy.

item.title: Ben Alder
item.description: May Day weekend 2000. A late dash to Scotland after work on the Friday. A long and dark post-midnight walk to the Ben Alder cottage bothy. A cracking day in the hills on the Saturday, begging Beinn Bheoil (1019m) and Ben Alder (1148m) as part of The Great Scottish Climb charity event.
item.content:encoded: May Day weekend 2000. A late dash to Scotland after work on the Friday. A long and dark post-midnight walk to the Ben Alder cottage bothy. A cracking day in the hills on the Saturday, begging Beinn Bheoil (1019m) and Ben Alder (1148m) as part of The Great Scottish Climb charity event.

item.title: Cona' Mheall
item.description:
Cona’ Mheall (978m)

Another long walk in and only a single munro bagged, in the mist and rain. Yuk!
item.content:encoded:
Cona’ Mheall (978m)

Another long walk in and only a single munro bagged, in the mist and rain. Yuk!

item.title: Ben Lui
item.description: On which we climbed Beinn a’Chleibh (916m) and Ben Lui (1130m).
item.content:encoded: On which we climbed Beinn a’Chleibh (916m) and Ben Lui (1130m).

item.title: The Aonach Eagach Ridge
item.description: A misty day scrambling along the Aonach Eagach ridge.
item.content:encoded: A misty day scrambling along the Aonach Eagach ridge.

item.title: The Glen Lyon Four
item.description:
A hot spring day taking in a circuitous route around the Glen Lyon four.

  • Carn Gorm (1029m)
  • Meall Garbh (968m)
  • Carn Mairg (1041m)
  • Meall nan Aighean (Creag Mhor) (981m)

item.title: Eididh nan Clach Geala
item.description: My second Munro. Lots of fun in the snow.
item.content:encoded: My second Munro. Lots of fun in the snow.

item.title: Meall a’Chrasgaidh
item.description:
Good Friday, 10th April 1998.

While the Good Friday Agreement was being signed in Belfast, I was reluctantly plodding up my first ever Munro, the dreary featureless lump that is Meall a’Chrasgaidh.

Only the view across to the mighty An Teallach served to convince me that it was perhaps worth giving this hillwalking lark another try.
item.content:encoded:
Good Friday, 10th April 1998.

While the Good Friday Agreement was being signed in Belfast, I was reluctantly plodding up my first ever Munro, the dreary featureless lump that is Meall a’Chrasgaidh.

Only the view across to the mighty An Teallach served to convince me that it was perhaps worth giving this hillwalking lark another try.
